thread.title: New Ross mourns Lalo Malone, former Lebanon peacekeeper and beloved family man
thread.title_full: New Ross mourns Lalo Malone, former Lebanon peacekeeper and beloved family man

author: Independent.ie
title: New Ross mourns Lalo Malone, former Lebanon peacekeeper and beloved family man
text:
New Ross mourns Lalo Malone, former Lebanon peacekeeper and beloved family man
The passing of New Ross man Lalo Malone – a former peacekeeper in Lebanon with the UN – was marked with a military send off in his native town.
Late of 40 Hewittsland, New Ross, Lalo died suddenly aged 63 at his home on Sunday, February 18.
Lalo grew up in Pondfields, in a large family of five brothers and five sisters. From a young age he was a character. This was borne out in too many incidents to list here, but one involving his sister Marian, immediately comes to mind. He was born nine months before his sister and lived in her shadow growing up, so much so that he followed her into Communion classes and ended up having his Communion a year early through sheer determination and neck.
He was a loving son of his parents Emmy and Larry. Sports mad from childhood, he won a Leinster championship title in boxing. He also lined out in Geraldine O’Hanrahan’s hurling teams and for local football teams, also enjoying handball.
He joined the FCA as a teenager and went on to join the armed forces.
Lalo was based at Stephen’s Barracks in Kilkenny City where his brother Martin and brother-in-law Philip were both stationed. He went on to serve four tours as a peacekeeper in Lebanon, during periods of hot conflict there. In later years he would often recall his time there, during which he learnt Arabic phrases, which he often shared with his sister’s partner, who is Arabian.
A great friend of Johnny Goggins since childhood, Lalo even learnt the Traveller language. He also forged great friendships with Neil Stacey, Patsy Connolly and current Kilkenny Mayor, Joe Malone, with whom he served in the army.
Lalo met Elaine, who had moved to New Ross from her native Celbridge, Co Kildare, through his sister Marian, who was married to Elaine’s brother Philip.
They were married and Lalo adored his children, Amanda, Charlene, David, Laura, Gary and the late Steven. The family lived at Neville Street, Barrack Lane and later at Maiden Lane, prior to Lalo settling at Hewittsland.
Lalo loved bringing his sons fishing with him, enjoying many an outing together.
Lalo’s sister Mary Lou said her brother was a fun loving prankster, someone who loved learning and watching documentaries, and spending time with his children and 15 grandchildren.
He did a counselling course in the Nineties and enjoyed psychology. Having finished his time with the army, Lalo because a probation service supervisor in New Ross, where he worked for several years.
Aged 45 Lalo suffered a serious health setback, one doctors didn’t think he’d recover from, but he fought back. With the help of Mary Lou, Gary and David, Lalo was well looked after.
Lalo’s favourite pastime in later life was gardening at his home. Whether it was growing plums, rhubarb or pears, he was never happier than when sitting out in the sun in his garden.
He was a member of Óglaigh na hÉireann and Irish United Veterans association and proudly marched at various events over the years, decked out in his full uniform.
Mary Lou said her brother was a very good natured person. “He’d give you the last penny in his pocket and if he had an argument with you, he’d be back the next day to apologise.”
Lalo enjoyed life’s simple pleasures, especially cigarettes.
He was given a great send-off at his funeral mass at St Mary & St Michael’s Parish Church, where UN soldiers gave his remain a final salute as they were carried into the church, and also at his graveside.
His nephew Gavin was pole boy, dressed in full military uniform, as he marched with the coffin alongside Lalo’s 4-year-old grandson, Ben, who was also decked out in army uniform. Tributes were paid to Lalo by Mary Lou and Gary at the mass, after which Lalo was laid to rest in St Stephen’s Cemetery.
Lalo was predeceased by his loving son Steven, his father Larry and sister Amy. He is sadly missed by his daughters and sons Amanda, Charlene, Laura, David, Gary and their mother Elaine, mother Emmy, brothers and sisters Joe, Marian, Michael, Siobhán, Martin, Marylou, Oliver and Lorraine, grandchildren Caitlyn, Dylan, Emma, PJ, Nicole, Shane, Dia, Sophie, Lorcan, Lexi, Ben, Jake, Avie, Cooper, and Thomas, daughter-in-law, sons-in-law, brothers-in-law, sisters-in-law, nephews, nieces, extended family and a large circle of friends.
May he Rest In Peace.
